chapter.title: &RESTAPI; Resources and URI Patterns
chapter.para: URI paths provide access to &RESTAPI; resources. An application uses standard HTTP methods (GET, PUT, POST, and DELETE) to make a request and parses the response, which includes a standard HTTP response code.
The number of URIs is finite, and the API specification this developer documentation in combination with the &RESTAPI; resource reference () covers all possible URI patterns.

It is possible that the algorithm used to generate unique identifiers could change. It is good practice to always GET the current unique identifier rather than trusting the accuracy of a unique identifier you acquired in the past.

section.title: Resource Naming Conventions
section.para: URIs for API resource collections follow this basic structure:
REST API resources follow these naming conventions:

listitem.para: lowerCamelCase – Examples: students, studentSectionAssociations, and gradebookEntries.
Resource names are plural – Whether a URI refers to a collection or to a specific resource by its unique identifier, the name of the resource is plural.

section.title: Direct References and Associations
section.para: Resources in the REST API can refer to each other in these two ways:

listitem.para: Direct reference - A direct reference is an attribute of one resource that refers to another resource. For example, a course resource includes a school identifying the school to which it applies attribute.
When browsing the data model, direct references are listed in the table of attributes for each resource. Look for "Reference to" in the "Type" column to identify each direct reference.

Association - An association is a standalone resource that stores the relationship between two other resources. Associations have at least two direct references, one for each resource in the relationship. For example, the students and schools resources do not have direct references to each other, but a specific student-school pairing can be stored in the studentShoolAssociations resource, with a direct reference to both students and schools. In addition, associations may include attributes specific to that pairing. That studentShoolAssociations resource, for example, includes a student's entry and withdrawal dates for the school.
When browsing the API or data model, associations are listed alongside other resources. Look for "Association" in the title of each association resource.

section.para: Both direct references and associations provide helpful navigation between resources. In the following example, a GET request makes use of the sectionAssessmentAssociations resource to find all instances of the assessments resource associated with the specified sections resource:

section.title: API Versioning
section.para: If the you only define the major version, you are internally routed to the latest minor version of the major revision. For example; If v1.1 is the latest API version rest/api/v1/students is internally routed to rest/api/v1.1/students.
All the HATEOAS links in the response reflect the version requested.

section.title: Pre-filtering Context Resolution
section.para: An implied context is sometimes added to open-ended URIs that pre-filters the results. In these instances, open-ended URIs return only the current and directly associated entities. The context used for these URIs can be seen in the API reference information as well as in the HTTP header of the request. To return results that deviate from the implied context, such as past data, you must explicitly provide additional context in the URI.

listitem.para: For staff, the implied context is: /schools/{IDs}/sections. {IDs} represents a list of the school IDs to which the staff is currently associated.
For students, the implied context is: /students/{ID}/studentSectionAssociations/sections. {ID} represents the student's unique ID.

section.title: Basic URI Patterns
section.para: Each resource has two base URI paths: one that refers to the resource as a collection, and one that refers to a specific resource by the unique identifier of the resource. These are described below:

listitem.para: One-part URI. Refers to the specified resource as a collection.
The following example returns the sections resources that the user has access to.
Two-part URI. Refers to a specific instance of a resource by its unique identifier. A two-part URI provides a context for finding related resources. See .
The following example returns the specified sections resource.

note.para: A GET request can specify multiple unique identifiers in a comma-separated list.

listitem.para: The following example returns the specified sections resource.

section.title: URI Patterns for Resources in Context
section.para: A resource in context is expressed by a URI pattern that refers to a resource from the context of another resource, specifically, from the context of a two-part URI.

listitem.para: Three-part URI. Refers to the specified resource as a collection from the context of the first two parts of the URI.
The following example returns the collection of studentSectionAssociations resources that represents students who are enrolled in the specified section.
Four-part URI. Refers to the specified resource as a collection from the context of the first three parts of the URI. This pattern is typically used to request resources through their associations.
The following example returns the collection of students resources who are enrolled in the specified section.
Five-part URI. Refers to the specified resource as a collection from the context of the first four parts of the URI. This pattern is typically used to request resources through their associations.
The following example returns the collection of attendances resources for the students who are enrolled in the specified section.
Six-part URI. Refers to the specified resource as a collection from the context of the first five parts of the URI. This pattern is typically used to request resources through their associations.
The following example returns the collection of parents resources for the students who are enrolled in the specified section.

section.title: Resource Representations
section.para: Your application can choose to accept and provide content in one of these data-interchange formats:

The W3C XML Schemas that are provided with this documentation are intended to provide a machine-readable specification of the data attributes of the representation of a resource that is transferred as either a request or a response in the REST API. The schemas are applicable for both JSON and XML data formats with the understanding that JSON attribute names become XML elements and that JSON values become the content of those elements. However, these schemas are not suitable for direct validation of the XML using standard validation tools. In particular, the transferred resources will differ from the schema description in the following ways:

listitem.para: The JSON attributes/XML elements will have no particular ordering for responses and are not expected to be ordered for requests.
The schemas do not describe the id, entityType, links, and metaData JSON attributes/XML elements.

section.title: Examples of XML Resource Representations
section.para: The following example shows the XML response for a single students resource. Notice how the response is wrapped in a document element named EntityResponse.
The XML response for multiple students resources would contain multiple student elements, as the following example shows.
section.programlisting: <EntityResponse> <student> [ Fields for first student omitted for clarity ] </student> <student> [ Fields for second student omitted for clarity ] </student> <student> [ Fields for last student omitted for clarity ] </student> </EntityResponse>

section.title: Using HATEOAS Links to Navigate the Data Model
section.para: One way to find out which resources can be reached from a given context is to look at the HATEOAS links in the response body of a GET request. Each link provides a URI that can be used in a subsequent GET request.
The following example shows one method for navigating from sections to students.

listitem.para: Request all sections resources that the user has access to.
HTTP Request
HATEOAS Links (for one section)
The array of HATEOAS links in the response body shows all possible relationships and provides a complete list of URIs that can be used in subsequent HTTP requests.
The "self" HATEOAS link is the two-part URI that represents the context identifier for the resource. That is, the "self" URI can be used as the context for building three- and four-part URIs.
HATEOAS Link for "self"

Choose a HATEOAS link that refers to the resource that you want to view, in this case, the collection of students resources who have an association with the specified sections resource. Accessing students from the context of the specified sections resource requires a four-part URI, as the following example shows.
HATEOAS Link

section.title: Summary of URI Patterns
section.para: The following table summarizes the relationships between URI patterns and HTTP methods.

entry.para: Create a new resource using the data contained in the request body
Return the collection of resources that the user has access to
/sections/{sectionId1,sectionId2} (multiple unique identifiers are only valid for GET requests)
Return the specified resource or resources
If the specified resource exists, replace it with the representation in the request body, else error
Return the collection of associations for the specified context
Return the collection of resources for the specified context
Return the collection of resources for the specified context
Return the collection of resources for the specified context

section.title: URI Query Segments
section.para: Optional query segments can be appended to a URI path, to the right of a question mark ('?') character, to specify query constraints. Query segments can only be used in GET request URIs and are organized as one or more name-value pairs. Multiple query segments are separated by an ampersand ('&') character and denote a logical and operation over the constraints.
The &PRODUCTABBR; REST API supports the following methods for forming query segments:

listitem.para: Global parameters – for filtering, sorting, and pagination. See .
Query operators – for pattern matching. See .

section.para: Example of a URI that contains a query segment:

note.para: Although query segments can reduce or control the amount of data that an API call returns, complex queries can affect performance.

section.title: Search
section.para: Search functionality is available for select entities through the &RESTAPI; using specific search URIs. Search results are limited to only results for which the user has security context and are also constrained to no more than 250 results.
The search is a case-insensitive keyword search that finds "Starts with" matches on search terms.
For example, the search term "mat" finds the student "Matt Sollars" as a match.
For multiple word strings,trailing wildcards are assummed on each word.
For example, the search term "Hills" finds "East Hills High School" and "Hillsborough Middle School".
Full substring search is not currently supported.
For example, the search term "ollars" does not return "Matt Sollars" as a match.
The search fields are:

section.title: Custom Endpoints
section.para: Many entities have custom endpoints that make custom data accessible to applications. How these endpoints are used is up to the application developer. The syntax for the custom endpoints is entity name/{id}/custom. To verify that a specific entity has an accessible custom endpoint, see inBloom REST API Resources

A user must have context to the endpoint and must be able to access at least a single field of that entity to be able to read custom data. For writing custom data the user needs no rights. The application is responsible for managing write access to the custom endpoint since the application is adding the custom data.
Example: /courses/{id}/custom

If the user has context to /courses/{id}, then the user needs READ_*** rights such that it can access at least one field of the course entity to be able to read access to the /courses/{id}/custom endpoint.
